etymology.description: 大(大) (dà, "person") with a tattooed face for penal purposes -> ancient punishments -> dots added around 大 representing tattoo marks -> erroneously interpreted as 火(火) (huǒ, "fire") under a chimney causing blackening -> displaced 玄(玄) (xuán, "black")
etymology.interpretation: The character 黑(hēi) originally represented a person with facial tattoos, symbolizing punishment. Over time, its meaning evolved to represent the color black, replacing 玄(玄) (xuán, "black") which was previously used.
etymology.simplification: The character is not simplified in Chinese. However, in Japanese, the modern form 黒 replaces two dots with one stroke as part of orthographic reform.

examples.chinese: 这只乌鸦的羽毛非常黑(這只烏鴉的羽毛非常黑)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhī wūyā de yǔmáo fēicháng hēi.
examples.english: The crow's feathers are very black.

examples.chinese: 他的心情因为失落而变得黑(他的心情因為失落而變得黑)，看不出一丝笑容(看不出一絲笑容)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de xīnqíng yīnwèi shīluò ér biànde hēi, kànbùchū yīsī xiàoróng.
examples.english: His mood turned dark because of the loss, showing no trace of a smile.

examples.chinese: 黑色在时尚中代表神秘(黑色在時尚中代表神秘)。
examples.pinyin: Hēisè zài shíshàng zhōng dàibiǎo shénmì.
